text: [Music]
well Canadians and Americans have many
similarities and many of many most of us
in Canada have family in the US because
the families came over from wherever and
some went to Canada some went to the US
so in a way we're very similar in a way
we're quite different we live in a big
harsh cold climate and our ancestors
knew that if we didn't share we wouldn't
survive so we invested more faith in our
governments and Collective Notions and
social programs and East West links than
Americans I always say that our founding
motto or or um kind of ethos is is uh
sharing for survival whereas in the US
it's more survival of the fittest and
your founding principles life liberty in
the pursuit of happiness ours is peace
order and good government which is kind
of boring in you know in comparison so
we are a we have a different kind of
model and sometimes like when and I do a
lot of work here in the US but when I
come here sometimes I'm stunned by the
belief that everything's about the about
the market and about even the
environments about entrepreneurship
green entrepreneurship right as if
that'll somehow save everything and um I
and I was at a water conference in LEC
Texas a couple of years ago and and you
know they nobody would I mean they said
they put up this great big billboard or
this big PowerPoint at the first day and
just showed how the demand for water in
Texas is going right up and that the the
water supply is going right down and
this is a crisis and what are we going
to do they're tearing their hair out and
I said to them well you've got a private
system here and and big the big users
you know can buy their way out of
everything you got tboon Pickin as if he
isn't Rich enough going around buying up
acers water rights and sitting on them
right why don't you say no to that why
don't you limit the amount of water any
one person or Corporation can can own oh
well that would go against you know
capitalism and Entrepreneurship and the
market and they hate government and they
don't trust the government could any
ever do anything right so we kind of
struggled for two days at the end of the
second day I said well I don't think I
convinced you but on the other hand you
didn't answer the question you put up
yesterday morning which was that X you
know demand and Supply a lot of people
came up to me and said you really made
me think you know you really you really
made me think that maybe we've got to
start looking differently so that was a
real Clash of two different kinds of of
um thought processes you know but I have
fun in you I was on a call-in show not
long ago and this guy called in he said
you're a bleeding heart liberal and I
said hey I'm a Canadian I don't know
what that means you know so we had some
good fun with
it oh heavens you guys don't know
anything about us I tell you we could
blow up up there and I don't know I
don't think it would get first page on
the New York Times or anywhere we're
just it's funny when I've been doing
this book tour here people people at
home say well you've been reading about
such and such and I say of course I
haven't unless I go online there's no
news about Canada here it's just you
know we know everything I mean all the
all the all the I was in I was in
Hollywood or I was in Los Angeles for
the first time a couple of weeks ago on
every single Street Vine and all I mean
I know them this is part of our culture
in Canada too because all of your
networks all of your magazines all of
your movies come here I know everything
about New York I know about the St
Patrick's Day parage you know I know
everything is famous in Canada most
Americans know just about that about us
and you know we we kind of laugh about
it we kind of um you know feel a little
inferior sometimes and unloved and all
of that but it's a it's an interesting
phenomenon you know you are the US is
the big guy on the Block and most
Americans don't have to do anything
about us except we're where the cold air
comes from
